title: The Heart of Mid-Lothian, Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "In my father's time,there was mair search for silenced ministers about the Bow-head and theCovenant Close, and all the tents of Kedar, as they ca'd the dwellings o'the godly in those days, than there's now for thieves and vagabonds inthe Laigh Calton and the back o' the Canongate.

title: The Heart of Mid-Lothian, Volume 1
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "In my father's time,there was mair search for silenced ministers about the Bow-head and theCovenant Close, and all the tents of Kedar, as they ca'd the dwellings o'the godly in those days, than there's now for thieves and vagabonds inthe Laigh Calton and the back o' the Canongate.

title: Ringan Gilhaize, or, The Covenanters
author: Galt, John
snippet: The air I breathed was as suffocating as sulphur; Igasped with the sandy thirst of the burning desert, and my throat was asthe drowth of the parched earth in the wilderness of Kedar.

title: Ringan Gilhaize, or, The Covenanters
author: Galt, John
snippet: The air I breathed was as suffocating as sulphur; Igasped with the sandy thirst of the burning desert, and my throat was asthe drowth of the parched earth in the wilderness of Kedar.

title: The heart of Midlothian;
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: " In my father's time there was mair search for silenced ministers  about the Bow-head and the Covenant Close, and all the tents of Kedar, as they ca'd the dwellings o' the godly in those days, than there's now for thieves and vagabonds in the Laigh Calton and the back o' the Canongate.

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: " Ou, ay did he, or how should I have kenned I was to have the pleasure of getting you to mysel for a gliff, hinny ? But I have never been able to sa' into the fashion o' the hungry London breakfasts, lang as I hae sojourned in the tents o' Kedar ; a bit wizened toast, scarted ower wi' a scruffin' o' butter, and a blash o' tea, without milk or creem ; but if Mr. Charles had sooner advertised me, I could have had a rizard haddock, as well as a caller egg for ye."

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: "Ou, ay did he, or how should I have kenned I was to have the pleasure of getting you to mysel for a gliff, hinny ? But I have never been able to fa' into the fashion o' the hunarv London breakfasts, Tang as I hae sojourned in the tents o' Kedar ; a bit wizened toast, started ower wi' a scruffin' o' butter, and a blash o' tea, without milk or creem ; but if Mr. Charles had sooner advertised me, I could have had a rizard haddock, a* wefl as a caller egg for ye."

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: For thus hath the Lord said unto me, within a year, according to the years of an hireling, and all the glory of Kedar shall fail."

title: Oliver Cromwell's letters and speeches: with elucidations.
author: Cromwell, Oliver
snippet: I say, thou shalt understand that Letter ; thou also,looking out into a too brutish world, wilt then exclaim withOliver Cromwell, — with Hebrew David, as old Mr. Rouse ofTruro, and the Presbvterian populations, still sing him in theNorthern Kirks :Wo's me that I in Meshec amA sojourner so long,Or that I in the tents do dwellTo Kedar that belong !Yes, there is a tone in the soul of this Oliver that holds of thePerennial.

title: Oliver Cromwell's letters and speeches: with elucidations.
author: Cromwell, Oliver
snippet: I live,you know where, — in Meshec, which they say signifies Prolonging ; inKedar, which signifies Blackness : yet the Lord forsaketh me not.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: But mostly these things go by contraries — the fair young Davids mating with the maids, dark but comely, out of the patched tents of Kedar and the tans of dusky Se- pharvaim.
